subject: Re: [junit] Re: bad class file error with KitchenSink app
msgSnippet: I think this is a misnomer.  I am developing under GWT 1.4.60 with the 1.6JDK.   It is OK to use a newer release of the JRE/JDK,  you just can t use new
messageBody:
I think this is a misnomer. I am developing under GWT 1.4.60 with the
1.6JDK. It is OK to use a newer release of the JRE/JDK, you just
can't use
new features in Java 1.5 or 1.6 (like enums or generic types) if your want
your application to be translated into JavaScript.

-Eric.

On 11/8/07, Will McQueen <willmcqueen@...> wrote:
>
> Hi James,
>
> I'm using JDK 1.4.2, and it seems that I don't have a choice to
> upgrade JDK because GWT relies on a JDK version <= 1.4.2. GWT
> translates Java to JavaScript, and the source files (or class files)
> must correpsond to JDK 1.4.2 or earlier. Given this, it seems that
> JUnit 4.x is compiled with JDK 5+. Is there a way I can re-compile
> JUnit 4.x (safely), and still be able to use it (and all its
> features, like Hamcrest) with JDK 1.4.2 (except for annotations...)?
>
> Regards,
> Will
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "James Abley" <
> james.abley@...> wrote:
> >
> > On 08/11/2007, Will McQueen <willmcqueen@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi,
> > >
> > > I'd like to use JUnit 4.x with GWT, but I get the error shown
> below. I
> > > don't get this error if I use JUnit 3.x. I'm using command-line
> only,
> > > and I created the ant build file with GWT's "projectCreator -ant
> > > KitchenSink". I see other posts regarding JUnit 4.4, so it seems
> some
> > > people have gotten this to work. How can I get around this "bad
> class
> > > file" issue? For easy reference, here's the relevant ant target
> that
> > > fails:
> > >
> > > <path id="project.class.path">
> > > <pathelement path="${java.class.path}/"/>
> > > <pathelement path="C:/gwt-windows-1.4.60/gwt-user.jar"/>
> > > <pathelement path="C:/junit-4.0.jar"/>
> > > <!-- Additional dependencies (such as junit) go here -->
> > > </path>
> > >
> > > <target name="compile" description="Compile src to bin">
> > > <mkdir dir="bin"/>
> > > <javac srcdir="src:test" destdir="bin" includes="**"
> debug="on"
> > > debuglevel="lines,vars,source" source="1.4" >
> > > <classpath refid="project.class.path"/>
> > > </javac>
> > > </target>
> > >
> > > Help is greatly appreciated!
> > >
> > > Thanks,
> > > Will
> > >
> > > ==========
> > > C:\gwt-windows-1.4.60\samples\KitchenSink>ant -f
> KitchenSink.ant.xml
> > > Buildfile: KitchenSink.ant.xml
> > >
> > > compile:
> > > [javac] Compiling 12 source files to
> > > C:\gwt-windows-1.4.60\samples\KitchenSi
> > > nk\bin
> > > [javac]
> > > C:\gwt-windows-1.4.60
> \samples\KitchenSink\test\com\google\gwt\sample
> > > \kitchensink\client\KitchenSinkTest.java:8: cannot access
> > > junit.framework.TestCa
> > > se
> > > [javac] bad class file:
> > > C:\junit-4.0.jar(junit/framework/TestCase.class)
> > > [javac] class file has wrong version 49.0, should be 48.0
> > > [javac] Please remove or make sure it appears in the correct
> > > subdirectory of
> > > the classpath.
> > > [javac] public class KitchenSinkTest extends GWTTestCase {
> > > [javac] ^
> > > [javac] 1 error
> > >
> > > BUILD FAILED
> > > C:\gwt-windows-1.4.60\samples\KitchenSink\KitchenSink.ant.xml:18:
> > > Compile failed
> > > ; see the compiler error output for details.
> > > ==========
> > >
> >
> > Check what JDK version you're using.
> >
> > http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=class+file+has+wrong+version+49.0%<http://www.google.co.uk/search?q=class+file+has+wrong+version+49.0%25>
> 2C+should+be+48.0
> >
> > Cheers,
> >
> > James
> >
>
>
>


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
